  1. It is used to convert individual objects into a binary format that can be communicated across an arbitrary connection.
  2. The output of this function is a raw vector coded in the hexadecimal format

What is the output of the following R code:

x <- 1:10
test <- function(x) 
{ 
    if(x < 5) 
    { 
        x-1 
     } else 
    { 
        x / x 
    } 
} 
apply(as.matrix(x), 1, test)

X1 <- c(1,3,5)
X2 <- c(3,2,10)
X3 <- rbind(X1,X2)

What is the output of the following R code:

val <- 3
testhack <- function(a) {
    val <- 2
    val ^ 2 + hack(a)
}
hack <- function(a) {
    a * val
}
testhack(4)

What is the output of the following R code:

testhack <- function(a=5, vals) 
{
    if(missing(vals)) 
    { 
        b <- 1:10 
    } 
    else 
    {
        b <- vals 
    }   
cat("my function returns:", "\n")
return(b/a)
}  
testhack(a=5, vals=30:20)

What is the output of the following R code:

mystery_method <- function(x) 
{ 
function(z) Reduce(function(y, w) w(y), x, z) 
}
fn <- mystery_method(c(function(x) x + 1, function(x) x * x))
fn(3)

What is the output of the following R code:

testhack <- function(a1, a2=5) 
{ 
    b1 <- a1/a1
    b2 <- a2*(a1/a2)
    hack <- c(b1, b2) 
    return(hack)
} 
testhack(2, 5)
testhack(a1=5)
